Born Ariana Grande-Butera on June 26, 1993, in Binghamton, New York, the American singer and actress has captured the hearts of millions with her distinctive voice and powerful performances.

Growing up in a musical family, Ariana was introduced to music at an early age by her father, acting coach and musician Luigi Grande, who also encouraged her to pursue acting. She took part in local plays and talent shows while in high school at the State University of New York at Canton, where she performed alongside theater icons like Lin-Manuel Miranda.

Ariana's music career began with her 2011 signing with Republic Records. She released her self-titled debut album "Yours Truly" in 2013, which featured hit singles "The Way" and "Baby I." Her unique mix of pop, R&B, and electropop, combined with her strong vocal talents, garnered her international acclaim and a dedicated fan base known as "Arianators."

That same year, she starred alongside Zac Efron and Selena Gomez in the movie "The Last Stand," proving her acting skills alongside her music.
